Circle:

A circle is a simple closed shape. It is the set of all points in a plane that are at a given distance from a given point, the centre; equivalently it is the curve traced out by a point that moves so that its distance from a given point is constant.

*The Radius is the distance from the center outwards.
*The Diameter goes straight across the circle, through the center.
*The Circumference is the distance once around the circle.

Tips:When we divide the circumference by the diameter we get 3.141592654... which is the number π (Pi).

Circumference = π × Diameter

Diameter = 2 × Radius

Circumference = 2 × π × Radius

Area = π × Radius\u00B2

Example1: You walk around a circle which has a diameter of 100m, how far have you walked?
Solution:Distance walked = Circumference = π × 100m
= 314m (to the nearest m)

Example2:What is the area of a circle with radius of 1.2 m ?
Solution:Area = π × Radius\u00B2
= π × 1.22
= 3.14159... × (1.2 × 1.2)
= 4.52 (to 2 decimals)

Hexagon:

A hexagon is a six-sided polygon or 6-gon. The total of the internal angles of any simple hexagon is 720°.

*Number of vertices: 6
*Number of edges: 6
*Internal angle: 120°

Area: 3√3/2 × (side)²

Perimeter: 6 x side

Example 1:: Find the area of regular hexagon whose side is 7 cm.
Solution:Area of a hexagon equation is Area = (3×√3/2) × Side\u00B2
Here, side = 7 cm
Substitute the value of side in area formula,
Area = (3×√3/2) × 72
= 127. 31 cm\u00B2 .

Right triangle

A right triangle or right-angled triangle is a triangle in which one angle is a right angle. The relation between the sides and angles of a right triangle is the basis for trigonometry. The side opposite the right angle is called the hypotenuse. The sides adjacent to the right angle are called legs.

*The Pythagorean Theorem:One of the best known mathematical formulas is Pythagorean Theorem, which provides us with the relationship between the sides in a right triangle. A right triangle consists of two legs and a hypotenuse. The two legs meet at a 90° angle and the hypotenuse is the longest side of the right triangle and is the side opposite the right angle.
The Pythagorean Theorem tells us that the relationship in every right triangle is: a\u00B2+b\u00B2=c\u00B2.
Area = ½ × Base × Height

Example 1: Find the length of the hypotenuse of the right triangle if the length of the other two sides is 5 cm and 6 cm. Also, calculate the area of the triangle.
Solution:
Given,
a = 5 cm
b = 6 cm

using the Pythagoras formula,
c\u00B2 = a\u00B2 + b\u00B2
c\u00B2 = (5 cm)\u00B2 + (6 cm)\u00B2
c\u00B2 = 25 cm\u00B2 + 36 cm\u00B2
c\u00B2 = 61 cm\u00B2
c = 7.81 cm

Area of the right triangle
= ½ *a * b
= 1/2 * 5 cm * 6 cm
= 15 cm\u00B2

Square

The square is a geometric shape that belongs to the quadrilateral family because it has 4 sides. The 4 sides are the same length and are parallel to each other.

Area of a Square = Side\u00B2

Perimeter of a Square = 4 × Side

Example 1Find the area of a square of side 5 cm.
Solution: A square of side 5 cm would look like as shown aside.
Formula for the area of a square is (side)\u00B2.
Hence, Area of square = 5 cm x 5 cm = 25 cm\u00B2

Example 2: Find the area of a square of side 16 cm.
Solution: Side of the square = s = 16 cm.
Area of the square = (side)\u00B2.
= 16\u00B2 cm\u00B2
= 256 cm\u00B2

Trapezium

A convex quadrilateral with at least one pair of parallel sides is referred to as a trapezoid in American and Canadian English but as a trapezium in English outside North America.

Area = ((Side1+Side2)/2) × Height

Area = ((BC+AD)/2) × AE

Area: ½ x (sum of the lengths of the parallel sides) x perpendicular distance between parallel sides

Example 1:Two parallel sides of a trapezium are of lengths 27 cm and 19 cm respectively, and the distance between them is 14 cm. Find the area of the trapezium.
Solution:Area of the trapezium
= ¹/₂ × (sum of parallel sides) × (distance between them)
= {¹/₂ × (27 + 19) × 14} cm²
= 322 cm²
